pageProps.contentHtml:
factor theorem

Does there exist a holomorphic function f ⁣:D→C\func{f}{\D}{\C}f:D→C such that

lim⁡n→∞∣f(zn)∣=∞\lim_{n\to\infty} \abs{f\p{z_n}} = \inftyn→∞lim​∣f(zn​)∣=∞

for all sequences {zn}n\set{z_n}_n{zn​}n​ in D\DD with lim⁡n→∞∣zn∣=1\lim_{n\to\infty} \abs{z_n} = 1limn→∞​∣zn​∣=1? Justify your answer!
Solution.

Suppose fff is such a function. Certainly fff is non-constant, since it is unbounded near the boundary. For each z0∈∂Dz_0 \in \partial\Dz0​∈∂D, we δz0>0\delta_{z_0} > 0δz0​​>0 such that if ∣z−z0∣<δz0\abs{z - z_0} < \delta_{z_0}∣z−z0​∣<δz0​​, then ∣f(z)∣≥1\abs{f\p{z}} \geq 1∣f(z)∣≥1, since fff is unbounded on the boundary. By compactness, there exist z1,…,zn∈∂Dz_1, \ldots, z_n \in \partial\Dz1​,…,zn​∈∂D such that {B(zk,δzk)∣1≤k≤n}\set{B\p{z_k, \delta_{z_k}} \mid 1 \leq k \leq n}{B(zk​,δzk​​)∣1≤k≤n} covers ∂D\partial\D∂D. Thus, if we let δ=max⁡1≤k≤nδzk\delta = \max_{1 \leq k \leq n} \delta_{z_k}δ=max1≤k≤n​δzk​​, then

∂D⊆⋃k=1nB(zk,δ).\partial\D \subseteq \bigcup_{k=1}^n B\p{z_k, \delta}.∂D⊆k=1⋃n​B(zk​,δ).

Hence, the zeroes of fff are contained in the compact set B(0,1−δ)‾\cl{B\p{0, 1 - \delta}}B(0,1−δ)​. Since fff is non-constant, fff can only vanish at finitely many points, or else they accumulate B(0,1−δ)‾\cl{B\p{0, 1 - \delta}}B(0,1−δ)​, which implies that fff is identically zero. Let {a1,…,am}\set{a_1, \ldots, a_m}{a1​,…,am​} be the zeroes of fff with corresponding orders {k1,…,km}\set{k_1, \ldots, k_m}{k1​,…,km​}. Thus,

f(z)=g(z)∏j=1m(z−aj)kj,f\p{z} = g\p{z}\prod_{j=1}^m \p{z - a_j}^{k_j},f(z)=g(z)j=1∏m​(z−aj​)kj​,

where ggg vanishes nowhere on D\DD. Thus,

1g(z)=1f(z)∏j=1m(z−aj)kj\frac{1}{g\p{z}} = \frac{1}{f\p{z}} \prod_{j=1}^m \p{z - a_j}^{k_j}g(z)1​=f(z)1​j=1∏m​(z−aj​)kj​

and sending ∣z∣→1\abs{z} \to 1∣z∣→1 and noting that polynomials are bounded on D‾\cl{\D}D, we see that

lim⁡∣z∣→1∣1g(z)∣=0.\lim_{\abs{z}\to1} \abs{\frac{1}{g\p{z}}} = 0.∣z∣→1lim​∣∣​g(z)1​∣∣​=0.

But ggg vanishes nowhere, so 1g\frac{1}{g}g1​ is holomorphic in D\DD. By the maximum principle, this implies that 1g\frac{1}{g}g1​ is identically zero, which implies that fff is identically ∞\infty∞, a contradiction. Thus, no fff could have existed to begin with.
